MC: The musculoskeletal system refers to the:

column3: a) bones and voluntary muscles of the body.
b) nervous system’s control over the muscles.
c) connective tissue that supports the skeleton.
d) involuntary muscles of the nervous system.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Introduction			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1146			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Introduction			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-1 Describe the anatomy and physiology of the musculoskeletal system.
MC
Skeletal muscle is also referred to as __________ muscle.

column3: a) smooth
b) striated
c) connective
d) involuntary

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Anatomy and Physiology of the Musculoskeletal System			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1146			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Anatomy and Physiology of the Musculoskeletal System			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-1 Describe the anatomy and physiology of the musculoskeletal system.
MC
Which of the following statements regarding striated muscle is correct?

column3: a) Striated muscle is involuntary because you have no conscious control over it.
b) Most of the body’s striated muscle is found within the walls of the blood vessels.
c) Striated muscle tissue is attached directly to the bones by tough bands of cartilage.
d) It forms the major muscle mass of the body and usually crosses at least one joint.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Anatomy and Physiology of the Musculoskeletal System			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1146			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Anatomy and Physiology of the Musculoskeletal System			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-1 Describe the anatomy and physiology of the musculoskeletal system.
MC
Which of the following types of muscle is under direct voluntary control of the brain?

column3: a) Cardiac
b) Skeletal
c) Smooth
d) Autonomic

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Anatomy and Physiology of the Musculoskeletal System			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1146			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Anatomy and Physiology of the Musculoskeletal System			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-1 Describe the anatomy and physiology of the musculoskeletal system.
MC
Atrophy is a condition that occurs when:

column3: a) increased use of skeletal muscle causes an increase in its strength.
b) the tendons that attach muscle to bone become stretched or injured.
c) muscle decreases in size and function because of disease or trauma.
d) carbon dioxide, lactic acid, and other wastes accumulate in the muscle.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Anatomy and Physiology of the Musculoskeletal System			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Pages 1146-1147			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Anatomy and Physiology of the Musculoskeletal System			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-1 Describe the anatomy and physiology of the musculoskeletal system.
MC
Skeletal muscle is attached to the bone by tough, ropelike fibrous structures called:

column3: a) fascia.
b) tendons.
c) cartilage.
d) ligaments.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Anatomy and Physiology of the Musculoskeletal System			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1147			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Anatomy and Physiology of the Musculoskeletal System			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-1 Describe the anatomy and physiology of the musculoskeletal system.
MC
Which of the following structures is regulated by smooth muscle?

column3: a) Heart
b) Skeleton
c) Blood vessels
d) Diaphragm

MC
What type of muscle contracts and relaxes to control the movement of the contents within its structures?

column3: a) Cardiac
b) Skeletal
c) Striated
d) Smooth

MC
Bone marrow produces:

column3: a) platelets.
b) blood cells.
c) lymphocytes.
d) electrolytes.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Anatomy and Physiology of the Musculoskeletal System			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1148			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Anatomy and Physiology of the Musculoskeletal System			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-1 Describe the anatomy and physiology of the musculoskeletal system.
MC
The pectoral girdle consists of the:

column3: a) scapulae and clavicles.
b) clavicles and rib cage.
c) sternum and scapulae.
d) acromion and clavicles.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Anatomy and Physiology of the Musculoskeletal System			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1148			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Anatomy and Physiology of the Musculoskeletal System			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-1 Describe the anatomy and physiology of the musculoskeletal system.
MC
Bones are connected to other bones by bands of tough fibrous tissues called:

column3: a) bursa.
b) tendons.
c) cartilage.
d) ligaments.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Anatomy and Physiology of the Musculoskeletal System			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1148			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Anatomy and Physiology of the Musculoskeletal System			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-1 Describe the anatomy and physiology of the musculoskeletal system.
MC
In moving joints, the ends of the bones are covered with:

column3: a) articular cartilage.
b) synovial tendons.
c) muscular fascia.
d) gliding cartilage.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Anatomy and Physiology of the Musculoskeletal System			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1150			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Anatomy and Physiology of the Musculoskeletal System			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-1 Describe the anatomy and physiology of the musculoskeletal system.
MC
A fracture is most accurately defined as a(n):

column3: a) total loss of function in a bone.
b) break in the continuity of the bone.
c) disruption in the midshaft of a bone.
d) abnormality in the structure of a bone.

MC
The disruption of a joint in which the bone ends are no longer in contact is called a:

column3: a) strain.
b) sprain.
c) fracture.
d) dislocation.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Pages 1151-1152			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-2 Name the four mechanisms of injury.
MC

A construction worker’s arm was severed just above the elbow when a steel girder fell on it. The stump is covered with a blood-soaked towel. The patient’s skin is cool, clammy, and pale. The EMT should:

column3: a) administer high-flow oxygen to the patient.
b) remove the towel and inspect the wound.
c) apply a tourniquet just below the shoulder.
d) wrap the severed arm in a sterile dressing.

MC: Complexity: Difficult			Ahead: Patient Assessment			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1159			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Patient Assessment			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-7 Describe the emergency medical care of the patient with an orthopaedic injury.
MC
Which of the following joints allows no motion?

column3: a) Skull sutures
b) Sacroiliac joint
c) Shoulder joint
d) Sternoclavicular joint

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Anatomy and Physiology of the Musculoskeletal System			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1151			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Anatomy and Physiology of the Musculoskeletal System			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-1 Describe the anatomy and physiology of the musculoskeletal system.
MC
A ____________ is a musculoskeletal injury in which there is partial or temporary separation of the bone ends as well as partial stretching or tearing of the supporting ligaments.

column3: a) Strain
b) Sprain
c) Fracture
d) Dislocation

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1156			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-3 Describe the different types of musculoskeletal injuries, including fractures, dislocations, amputations, sprains, and strains.
MC
Regarding musculoskeletal injuries, the zone of injury is defined as the:

column3: a) area of obvious deformity over the site of impact.
b) exact part of the bone or joint that was disrupted.
c) area of soft-tissue damage surrounding the injury.
d) part of the body that sustained secondary injury.

MC: Complexity: Difficult			Ahead: Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1151			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-4 Recognize the characteristics of specific types of musculoskeletal injuries.
MC
Which of the following scenarios is an example of a direct injury?

column3: a) A passenger fractures her patella after it strikes the dashboard.
b) A skier dislocates his knee after a twisting injury to the ankle.
c) A person lands on his or her feet and fractures the lumbar spine.
d) A child dislocates his elbow after falling on his outstretched arm.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1151			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-4 Recognize the characteristics of specific types of musculoskeletal injuries.
MC
An open fracture is most accurately defined as a fracture in which:

column3: a) fractured bone ends protrude through the skin.
b) the bone is broken but does not penetrate the skin.
c) a bullet or other projectile shatters the underlying bone.
d) an external wound is present over the fracture site.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1153			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-3 Describe the different types of musculoskeletal injuries, including fractures, dislocations, amputations, sprains, and strains.
MC
Which of the following musculoskeletal injuries would most likely result in deformity?

column3: a) Severe strain
b) Moderate sprain
c) Hairline fracture
d) Displaced fracture

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1153			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-4 Recognize the characteristics of specific types of musculoskeletal injuries.
MC
When assessing a patient with a possible fracture of the leg, the EMT should:

column3: a) assess proximal circulation.
b) compare it to the uninjured leg.
c) carefully move it to elicit crepitus.
d) ask the patient to move the injured leg.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1153			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-4 Recognize the characteristics of specific types of musculoskeletal injuries.
MC
A fracture caused by minimal force that is associated with diseases such as cancer and osteoporosis is called a __________ fracture.

column3: a) greenstick
b) pathologic
c) transverse
d) comminuted

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1153			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-4 Recognize the characteristics of specific types of musculoskeletal injuries.
MC
A(n) __________ fracture occurs in the growth section of a child’s bone and might lead to bone growth abnormalities.

column3: a) greenstick
b) diaphyseal
c) epiphyseal
d) metaphyseal

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1153			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-4 Recognize the characteristics of specific types of musculoskeletal injuries.
MC
The most reliable indicator of an underlying fracture is:

column3: a) guarding.
b) severe swelling.
c) obvious bruising.
d) point tenderness.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1154			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-4 Recognize the characteristics of specific types of musculoskeletal injuries.
MC
Deformity caused by a fracture would most likely be masked by:

column3: a) swelling.
b) guarding.
c) crepitus.
d) ecchymosis.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1156			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-6 Explain how to assess the severity of an injury.
MC
Crepitus and false motion are:

column3: a) indicators of a severe sprain.
b) only seen with open fractures.
c) positive indicators of a fracture.
d) most common with dislocations.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1155			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-6 Explain how to assess the severity of an injury.
MC
If a dislocated shoulder has spontaneously reduced before your arrival, the only way to confirm the injury is by noting:

column3: a) distal circulation.
b) the patient history.
c) bruising to the shoulder.
d) the presence of deformity.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1155			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-6 Explain how to assess the severity of an injury.
MC
Common signs and symptoms of a sprain include all of the following, except:

column3: a) swelling.
b) deformity.
c) ecchymosis.
d) guarding.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1156			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-6 Explain how to assess the severity of an injury.
MC
Which of the following statements regarding compartment syndrome is correct?

column3: a) Compartment syndrome typically develops within 6 to 12 hours after an injury.
b) Compartment syndrome occurs because of increased pressure within the bone cavity.
c) In most cases, compartment syndrome develops within a few minutes after an injury.
d) Most cases of compartment syndrome occur following a severe fracture of the pelvis.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Compartment Syndrome			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1192			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Compartment Syndrome			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-7 Describe the emergency medical care of the patient with an orthopaedic injury.
MC
Which of the following musculoskeletal injuries would pose the greatest threat to a patient’s life?

column3: a) An amputated extremity
b) Bilateral femur fractures
c) Nondisplaced long bone fractures
d) Pelvic fracture with hypotension

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1178			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Analysis			Objective: 32-6 Explain how to assess the severity of an injury.
MC
Of the following musculoskeletal injuries, which is the least severe?

column3: a) Nondisplaced pelvic fracture
b) Open fractures of a long bone
c) An amputation of an extremity
d) Multiple closed long bone fractures

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1153			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Analysis			Objective: 32-3 Describe the different types of musculoskeletal injuries, including fractures, dislocations, amputations, sprains, and strains.
MC

A 22-year-old female was ejected from her car after striking a tree head-on. As you approach her, you note obvious closed deformities to both of her femurs. She is not moving and does not appear to be conscious. You should:

column3: a) apply manual stabilization to both of her femurs.
b) administer oxygen and perform a rapid assessment.
c) assess for a carotid pulse and assist her ventilations.
d) stabilize her head and perform a primary assessment.

MC: Complexity: Difficult			Ahead: Patient Assessment			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1159			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Patient Assessment			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-7 Describe the emergency medical care of the patient with an orthopaedic injury.
MC
A 30-year-old man complains of severe pain to his right tibia after an injury that occurred the day before. The patient’s leg is pale, and he is unable to move his foot. The EMT should suspect that:

column3: a) the nerves behind the knee are compromised.
b) a severe infection has developed in the muscle.
c) pressure in the fascial compartment is elevated.
d) the nerves supplying the foot have been severed.

MC: Complexity: Difficult			Ahead: Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1152			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Analysis			Objective: 32-7 Describe the emergency medical care of the patient with an orthopaedic injury.
MC

During your secondary assessment of a 19-year-old female with multiple traumas, you note bilateral humeral deformities and a deformity to the left midshaft femur. Her skin is diaphoretic, and her pulse is rapid and weak. Your partner has appropriately managed her airway and is maintaining manual stabilization of her head. The most appropriate treatment for this patient includes:

column3: a) splinting her femur fracture with padded board splints.
b) immobilizing her to a backboard and rapidly transporting.
c) applying a traction splint to immobilize her femur.
d) carefully splinting each of her deformed extremities.

MC: Complexity: Difficult			Ahead: Patient Assessment			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1160			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Patient Assessment			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-7 Describe the emergency medical care of the patient with an orthopaedic injury.
MC

A 54-year-old male accidentally shot himself in the leg while cleaning his gun. Your assessment reveals a small entrance wound to the medial aspect of his right leg. The exit wound is on the opposite side of the leg and is actively bleeding. The patient complains of numbness and tingling in his right foot. You should:

column3: a) assess distal pulses as well as sensory and motor functions.
b) manually stabilize the leg above and below the site of injury.
c) gently manipulate the injured leg until the numbness dissipates.
d) control the bleeding and cover the wound with a sterile dressing.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Emergency Medical Care			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1163			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Emergency Medical Care			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-7 Describe the emergency medical care of the patient with an orthopaedic injury.
MC
Applying ice to and elevating an injured extremity are performed to:

column3: a) prevent further injury.
b) reduce pain and swelling.
c) enhance tissue circulation.
d) maintain extremity perfusion.

MC: Complexity: Difficult			Ahead: Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1191			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-8 Describe the emergency medical care of the patient with a swollen, painful, deformed extremity (fracture).
MC
In general, musculoskeletal injuries should be splinted before moving the patient unless:

column3: a) the patient is in severe pain.
b) the patient is clinically unstable.
c) deformity and swelling are present.
d) transport time is less than 15 minutes.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Patient Assessment			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1160			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Patient Assessment			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-7 Describe the emergency medical care of the patient with an orthopaedic injury.
MC
The primary purpose for splinting a musculoskeletal injury is to:

column3: a) prevent further injury.
b) maximize distal circulation.
c) make the patient comfortable.
d) facilitate ambulance transport.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Emergency Medical Care			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1164			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Emergency Medical Care			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-9 Discuss the need for, general rules of, and possible complications of splinting.
MC
The act of pulling on a body structure in the direction of its normal alignment is called:

column3: a) traction.
b) reduction.
c) stabilization.
d) immobilization.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1181			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-4 Recognize the characteristics of specific types of musculoskeletal injuries.
MC

A 21-year-old male was thrown over the handlebars of his motorcycle when he rear-ended a car that was stopped at a red light. He was wearing a helmet, which he removed prior to your arrival. He is conscious but restless and has closed deformities to both of his femurs. His skin is pale, his heart rate is rapid and weak, and his respirations are rapid and shallow. You should:

column3: a) bind his legs together on the backboard, keep him warm, and transport without delay.
b) apply traction splints to both of his legs, keep him warm, and transport without delay.
c) splint each of his deformed femurs with long board splints and transport without delay.
d) splint each of his deformed femurs with air splints, elevate his lower extremities, and transport.

MC: Complexity: Difficult			Ahead: Emergency Medical Care			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1164			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Emergency Medical Care			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-8 Describe the emergency medical care of the patient with a swollen, painful, deformed extremity (fracture).
MC
In which of the following situations should the EMT splint an injured limb in the position of deformity?

column3: a) When distal circulation and neurological functions are absent
b) If transport time to the hospital is greater than 20 to 30 minutes
c) If resistance is encountered or the patient experiences severe pain
d) If a traction splint will be used to immobilize the injured extremity

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Emergency Medical Care			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1165			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Emergency Medical Care			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-8 Describe the emergency medical care of the patient with a swollen, painful, deformed extremity (fracture).
MC

You have applied a zippered air splint to a patient’s left arm. During transport, the patient complains of increased numbness and tingling in his left hand. You reassess distal circulation and note that it remains present. Your most appropriate action should be to:

column3: a) elevate the injured arm and reassess distal sensory function.
b) inflate the splint with more air until the patient is comfortable.
c) assess the amount of air in the splint and let air out as necessary.
d) remove the air splint and re-immobilize with padded board splints.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Emergency Medical Care			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1168			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Emergency Medical Care			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-7 Describe the emergency medical care of the patient with an orthopaedic injury.
MC
Traction splints primarily immobilize and secure fractures of the:

column3: a) hip.
b) pelvis.
c) femur.
d) humerus.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1181			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-9 Discuss the need for, general rules of, and possible complications of splinting.
MC

A 76-year-old male experienced sudden pain to his left thigh when he was standing in line at the grocery store. Your assessment reveals ecchymosis and deformity to the distal aspect of his left femur, just above the knee. Distal circulation and sensory and motor functions are intact. You should:

column3: a) apply a traction splint to realign the deformity.
b) flex the knee slightly and apply a formable splint.
c) apply padded board splints to both sides of the leg.
d) bind the legs together and elevate them six feet to eight feet.

MC: Complexity: Difficult			Ahead: Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1190			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-9 Discuss the need for, general rules of, and possible complications of splinting.
MC

During your secondary assessment of a 30-year-old male who fell 25 feet, you note crepitus when palpating his pelvis. Your partner advises you that the patient’s blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 120 beats/min and weak. After completing your assessment, you should:

column3: a) defer spinal immobilization and transport to a trauma center.
b) perform a focused physical exam with emphasis on the pelvis.
c) stabilize the pelvis with a pelvic binder and protect the spine.
d) log roll the patient onto a long backboard and transport at once.

MC: Complexity: Difficult			Ahead: Emergency Medical Care			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1168			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Emergency Medical Care			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-6 Explain how to assess the severity of an injury.
MC
Care for a patient with a fractured tibia and suspected compartment syndrome includes:

column3: a) applying traction to maintain distal pulses.
b) keeping the leg at the level of the heart.
c) immobilizing the leg with an air splint.
d) applying chemical hot packs to the leg.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Compartment Syndrome			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1192			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Compartment Syndrome			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-7 Describe the emergency medical care of the patient with an orthopaedic injury.
MC
The most significant hazard associated with splinting is:

column3: a) aggravation of the injury or worsened pain.
b) reduction in circulation distal to the injury site.
c) compression of nerves, tissues, and vasculature.
d) delaying transport of a critically injured patient.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1169			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Analysis			Objective: 32-9 Discuss the need for, general rules of, and possible complications of splinting.
MC
The most commonly fractured bone(s) in the body is the:

column3: a) clavicle.
b) scapula.
c) radius and ulna.
d) midshaft femur.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1169			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-1 Describe the anatomy and physiology of the musculoskeletal system.
MC
When caring for a patient with a possible fracture of the scapula, the EMT should:

column3: a) carefully assess the patient for breathing problems.
b) apply rigid board splints across the chest and back.
c) assume that minimal force was applied to the back.
d) recognize that scapular fractures are life threatening.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1170			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-3 Describe the different types of musculoskeletal injuries, including fractures, dislocations, amputations, sprains, and strains.
MC

After direct trauma to the left upper back, a 44-year-old male presents with diaphoresis and restlessness. His blood pressure is 100/50 mm Hg, his pulse rate is 120 beats/min and weak, and his respirations are 24 breaths/min and labored. Your assessment reveals abrasions and contusions over the left scapula. You should:

column3: a) hyperventilate him with a bag valve mask and monitor his oxygen saturation.
b) apply high-flow oxygen, perform a detailed secondary assessment, and transport.
c) focus your assessment on his scapulae and clavicles and apply high-flow oxygen.
d) apply high-flow oxygen, consider spinal precautions, and transport without delay.

MC: Complexity: Difficult			Ahead: Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1170			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-3 Describe the different types of musculoskeletal injuries, including fractures, dislocations, amputations, sprains, and strains.
MC

A 17-year-old football player collided with another player and has pain to his left clavicle. He is holding his arm against his chest and refuses to move it. Your assessment reveals obvious deformity to the midshaft clavicle. After assessing distal pulse, sensory, and motor functions, you should:

column3: a) perform a rapid secondary assessment.
b) straighten his arm and apply a board splint.
c) immobilize the injury with a sling and swathe.
d) place a pillow under his arm and apply a sling.

MC: Complexity: Difficult			Ahead: Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1170			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-7 Describe the emergency medical care of the patient with an orthopaedic injury.
MC
Which of the following statements regarding shoulder dislocations is correct?

column3: a) Posterior dislocations are most common.
b) They are caused by forced arm adduction.
c) Most shoulder dislocations occur anteriorly.
d) They involve the acromion process and humerus.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1171			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-3 Describe the different types of musculoskeletal injuries, including fractures, dislocations, amputations, sprains, and strains.
MC

You receive a call to a local gymnasium for a basketball player with a dislocated shoulder. Upon arrival, you find the patient, a 17-year-old male, sitting on the ground. He is holding his left arm in a fixed position away from his body. There is an obvious anterior bulge to the area of injury. You should:

column3: a) assess distal pulse, motor, and sensory functions.
b) gently attempt to move his arm toward his body.
c) place a pillow under his arm and apply a swathe.
d) flex his arm at the elbow and then apply a sling.

MC: Complexity: Difficult			Ahead: Emergency Medical Care			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1163			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Emergency Medical Care			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-3 Describe the different types of musculoskeletal injuries, including fractures, dislocations, amputations, sprains, and strains.
MC
A supracondylar or intercondylar fracture is also known as a fracture of the:

column3: a) radial head.
b) distal humerus.
c) proximal radius.
d) olecranon process.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1173			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-4 Recognize the characteristics of specific types of musculoskeletal injuries.
MC

A 31-year-old male fell and landed on his left elbow. Your assessment reveals that the elbow is grossly deformed, his forearm is cool and pale, and the distal pulse is barely palpable. His vital signs are stable, and he denies any other injuries. Your transport time to the closest appropriate hospital is approximately 12 minutes. You should:

column3: a) splint the elbow in the position found and transport.
b) gently manipulate the elbow to improve circulation.
c) gently straighten the elbow and apply an air splint.
d) apply a heat pack to the elbow to reduce swelling.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1171			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-10 Explain the reasons for splinting fractures, dislocations, and sprains at the scene versus transporting the patient immediately.
MC

During your assessment of a 29-year-old female with significant deformity to her left elbow, you are unable to palpate a radial pulse. Your transport time to the hospital is approximately 40 minutes. You should:

column3: a) splint the elbow in the position of deformity and transport immediately.
b) apply gentle manual traction in line with the limb and reassess for a pulse.
c) carefully straighten the injured arm and secure it with padded board splints.
d) make two or three attempts to restore distal circulation by manipulating the elbow.

MC: Complexity: Difficult			Ahead: Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1175			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-9 Discuss the need for, general rules of, and possible complications of splinting.
MC
A Colles fracture involves a fracture of the:

column3: a) distal ulna.
b) distal radius.
c) proximal radius.
d) radius and ulna.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1175			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-3 Describe the different types of musculoskeletal injuries, including fractures, dislocations, amputations, sprains, and strains.
MC
When splinting an injury of the wrist, the hand should be placed:

column3: a) into a fist.
b) in a straight position.
c) in an extended position.
d) in a functional position.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1177			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-9 Discuss the need for, general rules of, and possible complications of splinting.
MC
Which of the following fractures has the greatest potential for internal blood loss and shock?

column3: a) Hip
b) Femur
c) Pelvis
d) Humerus

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1178			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Analysis			Objective: 32-3 Describe the different types of musculoskeletal injuries, including fractures, dislocations, amputations, sprains, and strains.
MC

A 45-year-old female was the unrestrained passenger of a small car that rear-ended another vehicle at a moderate rate of speed. She is conscious and alert but complains of pain to both of her knees. There is visible damage to the dashboard on the passenger’s side of the vehicle. In addition to fractures or dislocations of the knees, you should be most suspicious for:

column3: a) anterior hip dislocation.
b) posterior hip dislocation.
c) a thoracic spine fracture.
d) fracture of the tibia or fibula.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1179			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-7 Describe the emergency medical care of the patient with an orthopaedic injury.
MC
A “hip” fracture is actually a fracture of the:

column3: a) pelvic girdle.
b) femoral shaft.
c) pubic symphysis.
d) proximal femur.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1180			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-1 Describe the anatomy and physiology of the musculoskeletal system.
MC

A 77-year-old woman slipped and fell on a throw rug and landed on her left hip. She denies striking her head or losing consciousness. Assessment of her left leg reveals that it is shortened and externally rotated. Distal pulses, sensory, and motor functions are intact. You should:

column3: a) manually stabilize her left leg, apply a traction splint, and then secure her to a long backboard or scoop.
b) carefully slide a long backboard underneath her, keep her in a supine position, and apply a splint to her leg.
c) place her onto a scoop stretcher, pad around her left hip with pillows, and secure her to the scoop with straps.
d) bind both of her legs together with triangular bandages and carefully secure her onto the ambulance stretcher.

MC: Complexity: Difficult			Ahead: Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1181			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-8 Describe the emergency medical care of the patient with a swollen, painful, deformed extremity (fracture).
MC
Femoral shaft fractures can result in up to _____ mL of internal blood loss.

Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1181			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-8 Describe the emergency medical care of the patient with a swollen, painful, deformed extremity (fracture).
MC
The most common and significant complication associated with fractures or dislocations of the knee is:

column3: a) neurovascular compromise.
b) internal bleeding and shock.
c) ligament and cartilage damage.
d) total depletion of synovial fluid.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1187			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-4 Recognize the characteristics of specific types of musculoskeletal injuries.
MC
A person who experiences a calcaneus fracture after jumping and landing on his or her feet would most likely experience an accompanying fracture of the:

column3: a) thoracic spine.
b) lumbar spine.
c) coccygeal spine.
d) symphysis pubis.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1190			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-4 Recognize the characteristics of specific types of musculoskeletal injuries.
MC
When splinting a possible fracture of the foot, it is most important for the EMT to:

column3: a) use a pillow as a splint.
b) leave the toes exposed.
c) apply a pneumatic splint.
d) observe for tissue swelling.

MC: Complexity: Easy			Ahead: Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1190			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Recall			Objective: 32-4 Recognize the characteristics of specific types of musculoskeletal injuries.
MC
A 17-year-old female dislocated her patella while playing soccer. Her knee is flexed, and she complains of severe pain. You should:

column3: a) make one attempt to return the patella to its normal position.
b) gently straighten her knee and apply a padded board splint.
c) flex her knee slightly more and assess for distal circulation.
d) keep her knee flexed and secure it with padded board splints.

MC: Complexity: Difficult			Ahead: Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1187			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Application			Objective: 32-10 Explain the reasons for splinting fractures, dislocations, and sprains at the scene versus transporting the patient immediately.
MC

A 20-year-old male collided with another player during a hockey game and complains of severe pain to the left shoulder. Assessment reveals that the clavicle is bulging anteriorly at the shoulder. The EMT should suspect:

column3: a) dislocation of the glenohumeral joint.
b) posterior dislocation of the shoulder.
c) separation of the acromioclavicular joint.
d) multiple fractures of the proximal humerus.

MC: Complexity: Moderate			Ahead: Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Subject:Orthopaedic Injuries, Page 1170			Title: Orthopaedic Injuries			Feedback: See Specific Musculoskeletal Injuries			Taxonomy: Analysis			Objective: 32-4 Recognize the characteristics of specific types of musculoskeletal injuries.
MC

You and your partner are preparing to apply a traction splint to a patient’s deformed thigh. As you apply manual traction, the patient resists your efforts and states that the pain is getting worse. You should:

column3: a) stop and splint the leg in the deformed position.
b) assess distal pulses and continue pulling traction.
c) gently massage the thigh muscles to relax them.
d) flex the knee and place a pillow under the thigh.
